Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Temporal Clustering of Hydrometeorological Extremes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this CAREER proposal is to examine whether extreme hydrometeorological events cluster in time. Temporal clustering refers to the tendency of events to occur together in time, with the occurrence of an extreme event affecting the likelihood of a subsequent event. The proposed work is delineated in three phases, with research motivated by the following main questions: Do extreme hydrometeorological events exhibit temporal clustering, and, if so, which key physical processes explain this behavior? Can outputs from General Circulation Models (GCMs) reproduce observed clustered behavior? Is it possible to take advantage of temporal clustering to improve the forecasting of hydrometeorological extreme events? The underlying hypothesis is that extreme hydrometeorological events exhibit temporal clustering that is controlled by climate processes.

The continental United States will be the focus as this area is plagued by a large array of natural hazards yielding extensive socio-economic impacts. Some of the most damaging hazards in this general area will be included: flooding and heavy rainfall, high and low temperature extremes, and tropical and extra-tropical storms. Cox regression models will be developed to examine the dependence of extreme events on climate processes. The methodologies build on analysis tools and data sets that the PI has used extensively.

This research represents a comprehensive step forward in the understanding of the frequency and causes of extreme events; this has substantial broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to examine whether extreme hydrometeorological events cluster in time. Temporal clustering refers to the tendency of events to occur together in time, with the occurrence of an extreme event affecting the probability of a subsequent one. The underlying hypothesis was that extreme hydrometeorological events exhibit temporal clustering that is controlled by climate processes.

This research provided new insights and tools to analyze extreme hydrometeorological events. It increased our understanding of the physical processes responsible for the temporal clustering of extremes, with particular emphasis on heavy precipitation and flooding. It also provided a new metric to assess whether global climate models can reproduce the observed clustering properties, as well as the physical controls of extreme hydrometeorological events. The hazards of extreme hydrometeorological events affect governmental policy on managing the consequences of extremes, as well as the insurance/reinsurance sector. Issues related to the capability of global climate models to reproduce the observational records are relevant to model developers and users.

Overall, we found that temporal clustering characterizes the occurrence of extreme events across large areas of the United States and Europe, and that different climate processes drive this behavior, depending on the region of interest. Moreover, global climate models were generally skillful at reproducing the temporal clustering of heavy precipitation events.

The knowledge, tools, and datasets developed in this work have enhanced methodologies to characterize hydrometeorological extremes and advance interdisciplinary studies of hydrometeorology, climate science, and applied statistics. The results of the different project phases have been described in peer-reviewed publications and presentations at national and international meetings. Overall, almost 30 peer-reviewed papers have been accepted or published in leading journals in the field.

The project?s educational efforts promoted an improved understanding of weather and climate, with a particular emphasis on extremes. This educational focus included the training of both current and pre-service high-school science teachers to incorporate the Next Generation Science Standards. We accomplished this by developing and teaching two teachers? workshops geared toward middle- and high-school teachers. We provided them with basic tools to implement the new Next Generation Science Standards framework to education, which has been adopted for Iowa since summer 2015. More than 30 teachers attended the two workshops.
